parts: There are two design issues I am having trouble with. In the section containing the <h2> tag "Why Choose SG Maths Tuition for Secondary Math Tuition in Singapore?", I need to get the images and text blocks aligned so that their tops and bottoms match up. In desktop view, the heights and widths of text block and image should be the same, but in mobile, only the width needs to stay the same (the height can be different for mobile view). Also, in mobile view, it appears that the first and third images in the section have some of their right side cropped off.

SG Maths Tuition
    Secondary Maths Tuition - Elementary & Additional Maths
    • 15+ years of experience
    • One to one / small group E Maths and A Maths classes
    • Comprehensive notes for each topic
    • Ample practice problems
    • Detailed monitoring of progress
    WhatsApp (65) 92997306 Contact Form

    Secondary School Maths Tuition in Singapore

    At SG Maths Tuition, we provide personalised one-to-one and small group tuition for Secondary level Maths (E Maths and A Maths).

    The lessons are anchored by Dr Ng, who has a Ph.D. in Mathematics and has over 15 years of tutoring experience.

    We tailor lessons to the needs of each student and provide customized study plans. Whether you're struggling with foundational concepts or aiming for top marks in your exams, we focus on making the study of math engaging, rewarding, and, most importantly, effective.

    Why Choose SG Maths Tuition for Secondary Math Tuition in Singapore?

    Highly personalized one-to-one and small group classes

    Students have different learning needs. We provide highly personalized lesson plans for every student and adjust the style and pace of teaching accordingly. This ensures each student gets sufficient attention and finds the lessons productive and effective.

    Experienced Tutor with Deep Mathematical Expertise

    Dr Ng is a private tutor with over 15 years of experience. Armed with a Ph.D. in Mathematics and B.Sc. First Class Honours in Mathematics from the National University of Singapore, he brings unparalleled knowledge and expertise. He is well-versed in the latest Ministry of Education (MOE) syllabus.

    Proven Track Record

    Many of Dr Ng's students achieve a two to four grade improvement over the duration of study. This is achieved by building a good foundation for each student, getting each student familiar with the different types of questions commonly asked for each topic, and consistently practicing all the common problem solving methods.

    Comprehensive and Customised Learning Materials

    Each student receives personalised worksheets, practice papers and study materials, all of which are carefully crafted to support their learning. We go beyond typical textbooks to provide materials that are exam-focused, ensuring targeted preparation for upcoming tests.

    Contact

    Contact Information

    Complete the form or connect with me directly using the details below.

    DN
    Dr Ng
    Founder & Tutor
    SG Maths Tuition
    WhatsApp +65 9299 7306
    Email Me
    integrated.math.tuition@gmail.com
    5-minute walk from Kovan MRT

thoughts.content: I’m looking at the CSS for highlights. On desktop, there are two equal columns with full height, ensuring uniform row heights. But I think the issue could come from the images' inconsistent aspect ratios, causing them to crop on mobile. On mobile, the layout changes to a single column with adjusted images and text heights. The aspect ratio might be causing the cropping issue.

So with the CSS setup, the images are set to maintain a 3:2 aspect ratio inside their container, using `object-fit: cover` to fill the space. This causes cropping on mobile if the images’ original aspect ratios are different. If the user prefers not to crop the images, adjusting `object-position` could help center the image within the container.

It seems the cropping issue arises because the images' aspect ratio doesn't match the mobile container's 3:2 ratio. Since the images are 4:3, cropping happens at the sides, especially on the right. A simple fix would be to set the mobile aspect ratio to 4:3, which matches the images and avoids cropping.

The images are all 4:3, so the mobile container’s aspect ratio should be adjusted to match. On desktop, the layout uses grid columns to ensure equal height between the image and text. The problem might be caused by margins or border-radius affecting vertical alignment. I’ll adjust to fix the height and width consistency.

The issue seems to be with margins around the image's figure element causing misalignment. I’ll reset the margin of the `.highlight-media` figure element to 0. Also, I’ll fix the mobile aspect ratio to 4:3 and adjust the object-position to “center right” to avoid cropping the content’s right side.

I’ll suggest updating the aspect ratio on mobile to 4:3 and resizing the `.highlight-row` for equal column widths. For desktops, we’ll ensure both height and width are the same for image and text blocks by setting `height: 100%`. To prevent cropping, I’ll offer an optional CSS adjustment for image positioning to keep the right edge visible.

To address the design issues:

1. Remove default margins for equal alignment:  
   `.highlight-media { margin: 0; }`

2. Ensure columns have equal widths on desktop:  
   `@media (min-width: 961px) { .highlight-row { grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr; } }`

3. Adjust aspect ratio for mobile to avoid cropping:  
   `@media (max-width: 960px) { .highlight-media { aspect-ratio: 4 / 3; } }`

4. Optional adjustment for right-side image cropping on mobile:  
   `.highlight-row:nth-of-type(1) .highlight-media img { object-position: 60% center; }` 

This should fix the issues with image cropping and text alignment.

To address the design issues:

- **Remove default margin** for consistent alignment:  
  `.highlight-media { margin: 0; }`

- **Adjust aspect ratio** for mobile:  
  `@media (max-width: 960px) { .highlight-media { aspect-ratio: 4 / 3; } }`

- **Force 50/50 columns on desktop**:  
  `@media (min-width: 961px) { .highlight-row { grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr; } }`

Apply the patch to `assets/css/secondary-maths.css` at the bottom to override earlier styles.

parts: Are your changes scalable so that I can add more alternating text-image blocks?

thoughts.content: To address scalability for alternating text-image blocks, I need to check the uploaded HTML and CSS files. We could use CSS grid for structure, ensuring equal heights for desktop and auto-height on mobile. Reversing columns for even/odd blocks on desktop with stacking on mobile is a good approach.

thoughts.summary: Providing flexible CSS for alternating blocks
thoughts.content: To create a scalable system with alternating text-image blocks, I’ll use CSS grid for desktop display with equal columns. For reversing order, I can rely on classes like `.is-reversed` or the `order` property. I'll also adjust for mobile by setting images to fill widths and adjusting their heights as needed.

It seems like the earlier fixed 4/3 aspect-ratio on mobile was causing cropping, which contradicts the request for flexible heights. Since the user wants consistent width, I’ll remove the aspect-ratio, set width to 100%, and let the height adjust naturally with `height: auto` to avoid unexpected cropping.

The cropping issue on mobile was caused by using `object-fit: cover` with a fixed aspect ratio. To resolve this, I'll remove the aspect ratio for mobile to rely on the image's natural ratio. This will help avoid cropping, making things simpler without enforcing arbitrary aspect ratios on new assets.

For scalability, the best approach is to remove fixed aspect-ratio on mobile unless the user applies a consistent ratio across assets. I’ll propose two options: standardized (retain 4/3 ratio for marketing) or mixed assets (unset ratio). I'll adjust the CSS accordingly using classes like `.highlight-media--fluid` and review the uploaded files for class alignment.

thoughts.content: I’ve found the relevant CSS, and it looks like aspect-ratio is set to 3/2 in `secondary-maths.css`. This causes cropping when `object-fit: cover` is applied to certain images, particularly in `.highlight-media img`. The issue likely arises from a mismatch between the container’s aspect-ratio and the image itself, leading to right-side cropping.

thoughts.summary: Fixing the cropping and height issue
thoughts.content: The cropping happens because of `object-fit: cover` combined with a fixed aspect ratio. To prevent cropping, we could either use `object-fit: contain` (but that would add letterboxing) or remove the enforced aspect ratio. Since height differences are allowed on mobile, removing the forced aspect ratio and setting height to auto seems best to ensure the full image is visible.

The default margin (`1em 40px`) for figures might be causing top/bottom misalignment, as the margin isn't reset in their CSS. The grid rows are set with `min-height`, but the extra space from the margin in `.highlight-media` is disrupting alignment. Resetting the margin to `0` should fix this.

To reverse the order for alternating text-image blocks, we'll use `:nth-child(even)` and keep the grid with two columns. On mobile, we'll reset the order for even rows. For desktop, the key is to ensure equal column widths using `grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr`, which keeps the layout consistent.

To ensure scalability for alternating text-image blocks and avoid cropping, I’ll suggest maintaining equal column widths on desktop with `1fr 1fr` grid layout. On mobile, setting `aspect-ratio: auto` and `height: auto` will prevent cropping, maintaining the image ratio. Additional adjustments ensure uniformity and flexibility.

parts: How do I increase the gap between the h2 tag and the blocks?

thoughts.content: The gap between the image and the text could be caused by margin or padding settings, like the margin-bottom on h2 or margin-top on the grid container. There might be margin collapse between them. I’ll check the CSS for rules on h2 margins and propose a fix, like using `margin-block-end` or adjusting padding. Let’s explore the files.

thoughts.content: It looks like the gap issue under the `.section-title`—where the `h2` tag isn’t getting proper margins—might be caused by a missing dot in the CSS selector. The styles aren’t properly overriding because the tag selector `section-title` is used instead of `.section-title`. This is likely why the margin isn’t applied as expected.

It seems like a typo in the page-specific CSS is causing the styles to not apply properly. The missing dot prevents `.section-title` from being targeted, so the default margin of 12px is applied instead. To avoid affecting other sections, I can target `.section--highlights > .section-title` specifically and increase the margin-bottom there.

The vertical gap between the `h2` and the blocks may come from the margin-bottom on `h2`, combined with the top margin of `.highlights`. Since `.highlights` has no top margin, the `h2` margin defines the spacing. I suggest fixing the bug in the CSS selector and increasing the margin-bottom for better spacing, using `clamp`. I'll check if any other rule overrides it within the section.

It seems the rule for `.section--split > .section-title` isn't related to the highlights section—it targets a different part. The missing override for `.section-title` could be why the styles aren’t applying as expected, keeping the element at its default width. I'll examine more of the CSS for better context to address the gap issue.

thoughts.content: After reviewing the CSS corrections, I found that the `.section-title` class is now correctly defined with a dot, unlike the earlier incorrect snippet. The page-specific CSS sets properties like `max-width`, but it doesn’t include `margin-bottom`. Since the page CSS loads after the base CSS, it should ideally override all previous rules, including `margin-bottom`. I’ll confirm this for sure.

In CSS, when properties aren't overridden, previous ones stay. Since `.section-title` doesn't specify `margin-bottom`, the existing 12px from the earlier rule stays in effect. The user wants more gap, so I propose adjusting the margin for `.section--highlights > .section-title` without causing margin collapse in the `.highlights` section.

Margins between `h2` and its following container won’t collapse, so the gap should work. We can either add `margin-top` to `.section--highlights` or `padding-top` to `.highlights` for control. For spacing beneath the `h2`, we can either use a CSS variable for rhythm or set an inline class to adjust easily.

I’ll propose adding a margin to `.section--highlights > .section-title` to increase the gap under the heading. Alternatively, we can define the `--section-title-gap` custom property, but that's probably overkill. Also, the base theme’s existing margin might be too small for the new heading; I'll suggest overriding it.

The gap below the "Why Choose" heading is controlled by the `margin-bottom` of `.section-title` (set to 12px in the base CSS). We suggest overriding this with `clamp` to create a responsive gap. Two options are offered: local override or global edge-case adjustments via CSS variables.

parts:
Short answer: bump the bottom margin on that specific `

`. ### What controls the gap now - The “Why Choose…” heading is `

…

`. fileciteturn2file2L24-L26 - Your base theme sets `.section-title { margin-bottom: 12px; }`, which is why the gap is small. fileciteturn2file12L67-L71 - The container that follows (`.highlights`) has no top margin, so the space is entirely the heading’s bottom margin. fileciteturn3file1L122-L128 - Your page CSS redefines `.section-title` (font, width) but does **not** change its margin, so the base 12px stays. fileciteturn3file1L1-L7 ### Drop-in fix (scoped to this section only) Append this to `assets/css/secondary-maths.css`: ```css /* Increase gap under the "Why Choose..." H2 */ .section--highlights > .section-title { margin-bottom: clamp(18px, 3.5vw, 48px); /* desktop gets more space, mobile less */ margin-block-end: clamp(18px, 3.5vw, 48px); /* logical alias */ } ``` That’s it—the gap grows because the next element (`.highlights`) has no competing top margin. fileciteturn3file1L122-L128 #### Alternative (global) If you want the larger gap for **all** section titles site-wide, change the base rule in `tuition-css-1.0.1-phase8.css`: ```css .section-title { /* existing props ... */ margin-bottom: clamp(16px, 3vw, 44px); } ``` (This will affect every `.section-title`, not just the highlights section.) fileciteturn2file12L67-L71 > Side note: keep your previous fix `figure.highlight-media { margin:0; }` to ensure text/image cards align cleanly; it doesn’t affect the H2 gap but preserves the row alignment.
